Award.AwardTitle: Education and Public Outreach at the Soudan Underground Lab
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the public outreach program at the Soudan Mine Underground Laboratory, the only place in the country where visitors can tour an operational underground high energy particle physics and astrophysics facility. The study of weakly interacting particles is at the forefront of both fields and is the primary objective of experiments at the Lab. The Lab is hosted in a Minnesota State Park, where each year approximately 4,000 of the Park's visitors venture 2,341 feet underground to see the facility. The main experiments include the Main Injector Neutrino Oscillation Search (MINOS) and the Cryogenic Dark Matter Search (CDMS). MINOS is a long-baseline neutrino experiment designed to observe the phenomena of neutrino oscillations, an effect which is related to neutrino mass. The CDMS detectors operating at Soudan are for a series of experiments designed directly to detect particle dark matter in the form of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs).

Two high school science teachers and three undergraduate interns will work in the lab over the summer. Their primary duty is to help give the twice-daily "physics tours" and explain the lab and the science to visitors of the park. They will then use this experience and their science education skills to improve the lab's outreach program and develop lesson plans and educational materials for use by the many school groups which visit the lab on field trips during the school year. They will also participate in research projects with the experiments in the lab, not only the larger MINOS and CDMS projects but several smaller ones involved with Research and Development for low background measurements. A half-time outreach coordinator works year round with school and community groups. This award will also support the annual Open House at the lab.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the education and public outreach efforts at two northern Minnesota particle physics labs, the Soudan Mine Underground Lab and the NOvA Far Detector Facility at Ash River. These house the "far" detectors for two long baseline neutrino experiments, MINOS and NOvA. The detectors in these labs measure how neutrinos from the NuMI neutrino beam have changed in the 500 mile travel from Fermilab (near Chicago), compared to measurements at the "near" detectors. How the neutrinos change along the way is one of the major fronts of high energy particle physics research, and making the importance and excitement of this research available to schools and the public was the purpose of this award.

The Soudan Mine Underground Lab was in the Soudan Underground Mine State Park, where visitors come to take an underground tour about the history of iron mining. The lab had been studying neutrinos, proton decay, and dark matter since the 1980's, and park visitors could take a "science tour" as well as a history tour. Many school groups also came to visit on science class field trips, and annual open houses were held for the surrounding community. This award supported the final phases of outreach at Soudan: as the MINOS data run finished, and CDMS moved deeper to SNOLAB. We also fully transitioned to an outreach program at Ash River. Although the Soudan lab is now closed, the state park uses the MINOS and CDMS tour materials to continue science tours.

During the summers, undergraduate interns and high school science teachers were hired to help give tours, improve and expand informational materials, and make lesson plans and classroom materials. The undergraduates also worked on research projects related to the experiments, and were particularly successful at data analysis with the MINERvA experiment, resulting in student authorship in refereed journals. Year round, the award supported visits to schools and community groups by the PIs and outreach personnel. With the closure of the Soudan Lab and the remoteness of Ash River, the last years of the award focused on making sure the experience could be preserved and instead brought to students in their classrooms. A neutrino planetarium show was made using new 360 degree video, and we did pilot tests of video-based remote tours linking middle school classrooms with scientists at both ends of the beamline.

The neutrino planetarium show debuted at the University of Minnesota Duluth's Alworth Planetarium, and has also been shown at the Bell Museum in St. Paul, Minnesota, and has traveled to rural and tribal schools and other state parks in portable planetaria at both UM Duluth and Metro State University (in St. Paul + Minneapolis).

The webpage https://nusoft.fnal.gov/nova/public/ is a continued resource for learning about these experiments. It features live data from NOvA and explanations of what you're seeing. It also has links to a number of informational videos about neutrinos and the experiments themselves, as well as captioned 360 degree videos. If you fullscreen these videos, you can click and drag to change perspective on a computer, or on a phone or tablet, just tilt it around to look in different places in the labs.
